title: Homestead National Monument of America: NPS Centennial
body: Explore This Park    Get Involved     NPS Centennial            NPS Centennial       The National Park Service turns 100 on August 25, 2016. As we lead up to the centennial, we invite you to participate in Find Your Park Experiences to learn, discover, be inspired, or simply have fun in national parks. Find Your Park Experiences offer unique opportunities to explore national parks both in person and online. Check out the experiences in this park or search all experiences to identify an opportunity that matches your interests. You can also share your national park story at FindYourPark.com. A Call to Action remains the foundation for our 2016 centennial preparations. It is the National Park Service's blueprint for the future, outlining the innovative work we want to accomplish. Homestead National Monument of America is a big part of this effort. Take a look at what we're doing and get involved!   Experiences      Become a Junior Ranger at Homestead National Monument of America  Discover the history of our ancestors at Homestead National Monument of America. Travel through the park and complete your Junior Ranger booklet while experiencing the exhibits in the National Homesteading Museum, the Palmer-Epard Cabin, and the Farm Implements Displays. Read more   Explore with GPS at Homestead National Monument of America  Discover where modern technology meets history by going on a GPS walk. Bring an adult to the Education Center at Homestead National Monument of America to check out a GPS unit. Then, it’s up to you to navigate through the tallgrass prairie and bur oak forest without getting lost! Use clues and GPS points to answer questions and find hidden mysteries, a great family activity! Read more   Fathom the Magnitude of the Homestead Act of 1862 at the National Homesteading Museum  This multipurpose facility brings the epic homestead story to life for visitors of all ages and demonstrates the true scope and importance of the Homestead Act of 1862. Read more   Find Your Roots Search Homestead Records  Over the course of the Homestead Act’s 123-year history, over four million individual homestead claims were made. Each and every one of these claims generated a written record known as a case file that was kept by the U.S. General Land Office. Today, these case files exist only as paper originals and are stored in the National Archives in Washington, D.C. The complete collection of case files created under the Homestead Act contains over 30 million individual pieces of paper. Read more   Follow the Path of the Quilt Discovery Experience  Follow the trail to learn more about quilt making and the history of quilts and how they truly are documents of history, reflecting who we were as a nation and a people. Read more   Geocaching Homestead National Monument of America  Welcome to Homestead National Monument’s Geocache program! The Geocache program is an opportunity for the public to explore using GPS technology while visiting a historic National Park. Geocaching is a high-tech treasure hunt using Global Positioning System (GPS) devices. The idea is to locate hidden containers, called geocaches, which usually have trinkets placed inside. Read more   View More Experiences for Homestead National Monument of America    Call to Action Projects      Nature Detectives at Homestead  In 2012, hundreds of youth and their families have participated in Homestead National Monument of America’s Kids in Parks - Nature Detective Series.  These program series are intended to connect youth to their natural surroundings, in particular the tallgrass prairie and riparian woodland by fun, hands-on programs. Read more   Connecting Cultures on the Prairie   In May 2012, Homestead National Monument of America connected with youth of the Asian Center in Lincoln, NE.  The monument brought 168 members of the Center to view the Homestead Act of 1862 and learn about the National Park Service, the monument and its resources.   Read more   Shedding New Light on the Homestead Story  Park Guide Stephanie Wagle, who is legally blind, has developed a vested interest in bringing the story of homesteading to blind people like herself.  Read more   Quilt Discovery Walk  Homestead National Monument of America partnered with community member Kay McKenzie and former Homestead Artist-in-Residence quilter Lucy Fazely to create a Quilt Discovery Walk. The Quilt Discovery Walk consists of 23 historic quilt block patterns that have been posted around the monument’s grounds accompanied by an interpretive guide that explains that explains the significance of each quilt block pattern.  Read more   The Impact of the Homestead Act on Immigration  The Homestead Act of 1862 was a land law used by the 37th Congress of the United States to distribute the available public lands to private individuals.  However, it went beyond the distribution of land and became the United States first accommodating immigration law; providing all necessary requirements for citizenship.
